Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-compliance with removal order due to custody arrangement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether an Ontario Court custody order prohibiting child removal from the province prevents deportation under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) Section 50(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant is a Nigerian citizen with two Canadian-born children; granted custody by Ontario Court with prohibition on removing children from Ontario; removal officer argued custody does not require physical proximity
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal based on custody order
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Ontario Court custody order does not create a statutory stay under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Nigerian citizen, failed refugee and humanitarian claims
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Remained in Canada after visa expiration and subsequent removal order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Enforcement of removal order would contravene judicial custody order
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Section 50(a) IRPA requires direct contravention of a judicial decision where the Minister had opportunity to make submissions
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Physical presence of parent not deemed necessary for compliance with custody order
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Ontario Court custody order, removal order, immigration history
Crimes.Application_Basis: Judicial order allegedly conflicting with removal authority
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Custody order, status in Canada, nature of parental responsibilities
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Prevention of deportation based on custodial rights
Crimes.Governing_Rule: A removal order is stayed only if enforcement directly contravenes a judicial decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence that custody order required mother’s physical presence
Crimes.Outcome: Dismissed, but removal stayed pending appeal resolution
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential separation of parent and children
Crimes.Cause_Description: Applicant sought to prevent deportation by asserting custody rights over Canadian-born children
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court reviewed custody order and immigration documents
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain legal status after visa overstay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Interplay between provincial family court orders and federal immigration enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Custody order did not mandate mother's presence in Ontario
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removal does not directly contravene custody order as physical proximity is not legally required for custody compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Direct contravention test under IRPA Section 50(a)

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether a foreign national’s custody of Canadian-born children precludes removal under IRPA Section 50(a)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) Section 50(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nigerian citizen entered Canada temporarily, overstayed visa, made unsuccessful refugee and humanitarian claims, obtained Ontario custody order prohibiting child removal from province
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal based on family ties and custody order
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Custody order does not prevent enforcement of removal order under IRPA
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national without permanent status, failed protection claims
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to leave Canada after visa expiry and finalization of removal order
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Removal would violate custody order and Charter rights
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Enforcement must directly contravene a judicial decision where the Minister had opportunity to be heard
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Nature of custody rights versus immigration enforcement authority
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal certification and interim stay of removal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa history, refugee claim records, Ontario custody order
Crimes.Application_Basis: Overlap between family law decisions and immigration enforcement
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Timing of visa overstay, legitimacy of custody order, immigration status timeline
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Cancellation of removal order based on familial and custodial obligations
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 50(a) applies only if removal directly contravenes a judicial order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof that custody depends on mother’s physical presence in Canada
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; removal stayed pending appeal
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of family separation and impact on children
Crimes.Cause_Description: Overstayed visa following rejected immigration claims, leading to enforceable removal order
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Court examined immigration file and custody documentation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions on unauthorized stay and removal
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with conditions of temporary stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Conflict between provincial family law jurisdiction and federal immigration authority
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Custody order was valid but insufficient to block removal under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Precedent holds that custody does not inherently require co-residence; removal does not directly contravene court order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Direct contravention standard under IRPA Section 50(a)
